docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic candidate, asked whether he knew about loans that his family's bank made to organized crime figures, said he "didn't know the extent " of the mobsters' activities, but he never forcefully denied knowing that they had received loans.

byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and ALAN FEUER

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your article on litigation against mak-rs of antipsychotic drugs (''Side Effects May Include Lawsuits,'' Oct. 3) did not address the main reason for the high volume of prescriptions for them:they often help patients. Most doctors are not mendacious ornaïve. They sincerely want to help patients, and won't continue to recommend medicines that either don't workor incur significant side effects. Most research studies, no matter how accurateor manipulated, may convince a doctor to try a medicine, but they won't replaceclinical experience over time. And anyspeakers on behalf of a drug lose allcredibility if they proselytize unrealistically.I fear that the relationship between doctor and patient is threatened if open discussion of the uses of medications,even for so-called off-label administration, is curtailed. And I fear that themoney extracted from pharmaceutical companies will impact the resources dedicated to the development of moremedicines. JEROLD J. KREISMAN, M.D.St. Louis, Oct. 3 To the Editor: Much of the pharmaceutical mess began with the public advertising of prescription drugs, which encouraged the industry to change from a business model emphasizing efficacy to one emphasizing marketability. Marketing is a cakewalk compared with pharmacology, and it comes with a Pandora's box ofpotential abuses.Moreover, saturation advertising distorts the patient-physician relationshipby manipulating patient decision-making and mocking professional diagnostic expertise.Real health care reform, as opposed to health insurance reform, must in-clude reinstating a prohibition on the public marketing of prescription drugs.Let truly effective drugs sell themselves. ROB ROWAN Mangilao, Guam, Oct. 3

docs.lead_paragraph: TOWNIES Would you like to break into my apartment right now? All you need is the address and the inclination and you will find the keys to my front door in my unlocked mailbox. You'll even find a note explaining the quirks of each key, which ones turn in time with the clock and which ones fly in its face, all for greater thieving ease. Everything I've ever owned is yours for the taking.

docs.lead_paragraph: Are you one of the 46 million Americans without health insurance? Well, you may not have that, uh, luxury for much longer. "A federal judge in Michigan on Thursday dismissed one of more than 15 legal challenges to the new health care law, becoming the first to rule that the law is constitutional," reports The Times's Kevin Sack. "The central question, which may ultimately fall to the Supreme Court, is whether the Commerce Clause of the Constitution gives Congress the authority to require citizens to obtain a commercial product, namely health insurance. Starting in 2014, the law will require most Americans to obtain health insurance ..."
docs.abstract: A federal judge backs the health care law's role in interstate commerce, but will the ruling fuel a backlash?
docs.snippet: A federal judge backs the health care law's role in interstate commerce, but will the ruling fuel a backlash?
